message.content:
Implement the following plan:

# Changelog Page for Marketing Site

## Context

LaxDB needs a changelog page to communicate platform updates — new league data, features, improvements. Inspired by [linear.app/changelog](https://linear.app/changelog) but adapted to LaxDB's existing design language (dashed SVG lines, serif italic headings, orange accents, staggered fade animations).

## Files

### Create

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `packages/marketing/src/lib/changelog.ts` | Types, categories, seed entries, filter helper |
| `packages/marketing/src/components/changelog-entry.tsx` | Individual entry component |
| `packages/marketing/src/routes/changelog.tsx` | Route + page layout (timeline, header, filter tabs) |

### Modify

| File | Change |
|------|--------|
| `packages/marketing/src/components/navbar.tsx` | Add "Changelog" link (desktop + mobile) between Blog and Wiki |
| `packages/marketing/src/components/footer.tsx` | Add "Changelog" link under Resources column |

## Data Model (`lib/changelog.ts`)

```ts
type ChangelogCategory = "data" | "feature" | "improvement" | "community"

interface ChangelogEntry {
  id: string
  title: string
  date: string              // ISO YYYY-MM-DD
  category: ChangelogCategory
  summary: string           // 1-2 sentences below title
  body: string[]            // Paragraphs
  highlights?: string[]     // Optional bullet points
}
```

Static array of entries. No content-collections / MDX — overkill for a changelog v1.

Filter categories: All | Data | Features | Improvements | Community (same tab pattern as `blog/index.tsx` lines 7-12, 52-74).

## Layout Design

### Page Header
- `max-w-4xl mx-auto px-4 py-16 md:py-32` (wider than blog's `max-w-screen-sm`, narrower than homepage's `max-w-6xl`)
- Title: `h1.font-serif.text-2xl.italic` (matches blog index and about page h1 patterns)
- Filter tabs: Exact same `border-b border-border` + active underline pattern from blog index

### Timeline (the core design element)

Desktop (md+) — asymmetric two-column:

```
  Jan 15, 2026    ●─── PLL 2025 Season Data
                  ┆    DATA
                  ┆
                  ┆    Complete game-by-game statistics...
                  ┆
                  ┆    • 156 games across 8 teams
                  ┆    • Player stats: G, A, P, GB, CT
                  ┆
  Dec 2, 2025     ●─── Knowledge Graph Explorer
                  ┆    FEATURE
```

- **Timeline spine**: Dashed SVG vertical line reused from `features.tsx` lines 29-47 (`<line strokeDasharray="3 3" strokeWidth="2" className="stroke-border">` with gradient mask at top/bottom)
- **Orange dot markers**: `size-2.5 rounded-full bg-orange ring-4 ring-background` — punches through the dashed line
- **Date column**: `w-[140px] shrink-0 text-right` — `text-xs text-subtle whitespace-nowrap` using `formatPublishedDate` from `@/lib/date`
- **Content column**: `flex-1 min-w-0 pb-16`

Mobile (<md): Single column. Timeline line at left edge, date above content.

### Entry Design

- **Title**: `font-serif text-xl md:text-2xl text-foreground italic` (LaxDB's serif signature)
- **Category**: `.text-label text-xs` (uppercase, spaced — existing utility in globals.css)
- **Summary**: `mt-3 text-[15px] leading-relaxed text-muted-foreground`
- **Body**: `mt-4 space-y-3 text-[15px] leading-relaxed text-foreground` (matches about.tsx)
- **Highlights**: Bullet list using about.tsx's pattern — `<span className="mt-1.5 block size-1.5 shrink-0 rounded-full bg-bullet" />` (line 52)

### How It Differs from Linear

| Linear | LaxDB |
|--------|-------|
| Solid timeline line | Dashed SVG line (site signature) |
| Sans-serif titles | Serif italic (Newsreader) |
| Multi-colored category dots | Orange dots + uppercase text labels |
| Dark-only | Light + dark via CSS variables |
| Collapsible sections | All content visible |
| "Now" title | "Changelog" |

## Reusable Utilities

| Utility | Source | Usage |
|---------|--------|-------|
| `FadeContainer`, `FadeDiv` | `@/components/fade` | Page entrance animations |
| `formatPublishedDate` | `@/lib/date` | Date formatting |
| `cn()` | `@/lib/utils` | Class merging |
| `.text-label` | `globals.css` | Category label styling |
| Dashed SVG line | `features.tsx` lines 29-47 | Timeline spine |
| Bullet pattern | `about.tsx` lines 51-72 | Highlights list |

## Seed Content (4 entries)

1. **PLL 2025 Season Data** (data, Jan 15 2026) — 156 games, player/goalie stats, two-point tracking
2. **Knowledge Graph Explorer** (feature, Dec 2 2025) — Interactive force-directed graph, color-coded nodes
3. **NLL Historical Stats 1987-2024** (data, Nov 10 2025) — 37 seasons, franchise history tracking
4. **LaxDB Goes Open Source** (community, Oct 20 2025) — Full stack open-sourced on GitHub

## Animation

- Entire page in `FadeContainer` (staggered children: 50ms gaps, 200ms delay)
- Title, filter tabs, and each entry wrapped in `FadeDiv`
- Spring physics: stiffness 150, damping 19, mass 1.2 (existing config)
- No scroll-triggered animations — entrance only

## Implementation Order

1. `lib/changelog.ts` — data model + seed content (zero deps)
2. `components/changelog-entry.tsx` — entry component
3. `routes/changelog.tsx` — route + timeline layout + filter tabs
4. Modify `navbar.tsx` — add link (Blog | **Changelog** | Wiki | Graph)
5. Modify `footer.tsx` — add link under Resources

## Verification

1. `bun run dev` from `packages/marketing` (port 3002)
2. Navigate to `localhost:3002/changelog`
3. Verify: filter tabs switch categories, timeline renders on desktop + mobile, fade animations play, dark/light mode both work
4. Verify: navbar link works on desktop and mobile hamburger menu
5. `bun run typecheck` passes


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/jw/.REDACTED.jsonl

If this plan can be broken down into multiple independent tasks, consider using the TeamCreate tool to create a team and parallelize the work.

import { createFileRoute } from "@tanstack/react-router"; export const Route = createFileRoute("/about")({ component: About, }); function About() { return (

About LaxDB

The lacrosse data platform.

What we do

LaxDB is building the definitive data layer for professional lacrosse. We aggregate, normalize, and serve statistics across the PLL, NLL, MLL, MSL, and WLA — leagues that have historically kept their data siloed and inconsistent.

The result is a single platform where player careers can be traced across leagues and eras, where game data is structured and queryable, and where the sport's history is preserved in a format that's actually useful.

Why it matters

Lacrosse is the fastest-growing sport in North America but its data infrastructure hasn't kept pace. Box scores disappear when league websites shut down. Career stats are scattered across PDFs, spreadsheets, and defunct websites. Comparing a PLL attackman's production to an NLL forward's requires manual work that almost nobody does.

We think the sport deserves better. Good data doesn't just serve analysts — it deepens every fan's understanding of what they're watching.

How it works

  • Pipeline — automated ingestion from league APIs, historical archives, and structured scraping of public sources.
  • Normalization — unified schemas that reconcile different league formats, naming conventions, and statistical categories.
  • Knowledge graph — entities linked by relationships (teammates, opponents, career paths) enabling discovery and analysis.

Open source

LaxDB is open source. The data pipeline, API, and this website are all public. We believe lacrosse data should be accessible to everyone — fans, journalists, coaches, analysts, and developers building tools for the sport.

View on GitHub

Contact

For questions, data corrections, or partnership inquiries:{" "} jack@laxdb.io

file.content:
# Changelog Page for Marketing Site

## Context

LaxDB needs a changelog page to communicate platform updates — new league data, features, improvements. Inspired by [linear.app/changelog](https://linear.app/changelog) but adapted to LaxDB's existing design language (dashed SVG lines, serif italic headings, orange accents, staggered fade animations).

## Files

### Create

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `packages/marketing/src/lib/changelog.ts` | Types, categories, seed entries, filter helper |
| `packages/marketing/src/components/changelog-entry.tsx` | Individual entry component |
| `packages/marketing/src/routes/changelog.tsx` | Route + page layout (timeline, header, filter tabs) |

### Modify

| File | Change |
|------|--------|
| `packages/marketing/src/components/navbar.tsx` | Add "Changelog" link (desktop + mobile) between Blog and Wiki |
| `packages/marketing/src/components/footer.tsx` | Add "Changelog" link under Resources column |

## Data Model (`lib/changelog.ts`)

```ts
type ChangelogCategory = "data" | "feature" | "improvement" | "community"

interface ChangelogEntry {
  id: string
  title: string
  date: string              // ISO YYYY-MM-DD
  category: ChangelogCategory
  summary: string           // 1-2 sentences below title
  body: string[]            // Paragraphs
  highlights?: string[]     // Optional bullet points
}
```

Static array of entries. No content-collections / MDX — overkill for a changelog v1.

Filter categories: All | Data | Features | Improvements | Community (same tab pattern as `blog/index.tsx` lines 7-12, 52-74).

## Layout Design

### Page Header
- `max-w-4xl mx-auto px-4 py-16 md:py-32` (wider than blog's `max-w-screen-sm`, narrower than homepage's `max-w-6xl`)
- Title: `h1.font-serif.text-2xl.italic` (matches blog index and about page h1 patterns)
- Filter tabs: Exact same `border-b border-border` + active underline pattern from blog index

### Timeline (the core design element)

Desktop (md+) — asymmetric two-column:

```
  Jan 15, 2026    ●─── PLL 2025 Season Data
                  ┆    DATA
                  ┆
                  ┆    Complete game-by-game statistics...
                  ┆
                  ┆    • 156 games across 8 teams
                  ┆    • Player stats: G, A, P, GB, CT
                  ┆
  Dec 2, 2025     ●─── Knowledge Graph Explorer
                  ┆    FEATURE
```

- **Timeline spine**: Dashed SVG vertical line reused from `features.tsx` lines 29-47 (`<line strokeDasharray="3 3" strokeWidth="2" className="stroke-border">` with gradient mask at top/bottom)
- **Orange dot markers**: `size-2.5 rounded-full bg-orange ring-4 ring-background` — punches through the dashed line
- **Date column**: `w-[140px] shrink-0 text-right` — `text-xs text-subtle whitespace-nowrap` using `formatPublishedDate` from `@/lib/date`
- **Content column**: `flex-1 min-w-0 pb-16`

Mobile (<md): Single column. Timeline line at left edge, date above content.

### Entry Design

- **Title**: `font-serif text-xl md:text-2xl text-foreground italic` (LaxDB's serif signature)
- **Category**: `.text-label text-xs` (uppercase, spaced — existing utility in globals.css)
- **Summary**: `mt-3 text-[15px] leading-relaxed text-muted-foreground`
- **Body**: `mt-4 space-y-3 text-[15px] leading-relaxed text-foreground` (matches about.tsx)
- **Highlights**: Bullet list using about.tsx's pattern — `<span className="mt-1.5 block size-1.5 shrink-0 rounded-full bg-bullet" />` (line 52)

### How It Differs from Linear

| Linear | LaxDB |
|--------|-------|
| Solid timeline line | Dashed SVG line (site signature) |
| Sans-serif titles | Serif italic (Newsreader) |
| Multi-colored category dots | Orange dots + uppercase text labels |
| Dark-only | Light + dark via CSS variables |
| Collapsible sections | All content visible |
| "Now" title | "Changelog" |

## Reusable Utilities

| Utility | Source | Usage |
|---------|--------|-------|
| `FadeContainer`, `FadeDiv` | `@/components/fade` | Page entrance animations |
| `formatPublishedDate` | `@/lib/date` | Date formatting |
| `cn()` | `@/lib/utils` | Class merging |
| `.text-label` | `globals.css` | Category label styling |
| Dashed SVG line | `features.tsx` lines 29-47 | Timeline spine |
| Bullet pattern | `about.tsx` lines 51-72 | Highlights list |

## Seed Content (4 entries)

1. **PLL 2025 Season Data** (data, Jan 15 2026) — 156 games, player/goalie stats, two-point tracking
2. **Knowledge Graph Explorer** (feature, Dec 2 2025) — Interactive force-directed graph, color-coded nodes
3. **NLL Historical Stats 1987-2024** (data, Nov 10 2025) — 37 seasons, franchise history tracking
4. **LaxDB Goes Open Source** (community, Oct 20 2025) — Full stack open-sourced on GitHub

## Animation

- Entire page in `FadeContainer` (staggered children: 50ms gaps, 200ms delay)
- Title, filter tabs, and each entry wrapped in `FadeDiv`
- Spring physics: stiffness 150, damping 19, mass 1.2 (existing config)
- No scroll-triggered animations — entrance only

## Implementation Order

1. `lib/changelog.ts` — data model + seed content (zero deps)
2. `components/changelog-entry.tsx` — entry component
3. `routes/changelog.tsx` — route + timeline layout + filter tabs
4. Modify `navbar.tsx` — add link (Blog | **Changelog** | Wiki | Graph)
5. Modify `footer.tsx` — add link under Resources

## Verification

1. `bun run dev` from `packages/marketing` (port 3002)
2. Navigate to `localhost:3002/changelog`
3. Verify: filter tabs switch categories, timeline renders on desktop + mobile, fade animations play, dark/light mode both work
4. Verify: navbar link works on desktop and mobile hamburger menu
5. `bun run typecheck` passes

About LaxDB

The lacrosse data platform.

What we do

18→

19→ LaxDB is building the definitive data layer for professional lacrosse. We aggregate, 20→ normalize, and serve statistics across the PLL, NLL, MLL, MSL, and WLA — leagues that 21→ have historically kept their data siloed and inconsistent. 22→

23→

24→ The result is a single platform where player careers can be traced across leagues and 25→ eras, where game data is structured and queryable, and where the sport's history is 26→ preserved in a format that's actually useful. 27→

Why it matters

34→

35→ Lacrosse is the fastest-growing sport in North America but its data infrastructure 36→ hasn't kept pace. Box scores disappear when league websites shut down. Career stats are 37→ scattered across PDFs, spreadsheets, and defunct websites. Comparing a PLL attackman's 38→ production to an NLL forward's requires manual work that almost nobody does. 39→

40→

41→ We think the sport deserves better. Good data doesn't just serve analysts — it deepens 42→ every fan's understanding of what they're watching. 43→

1→name: Release
     2→
     3→on:
     4→  push:
     5→    branches:
     6→      - main
     7→    tags:
     8→      - "v*"
     9→
    10→permissions:
    11→  contents: write
    12→
    13→jobs:
    14→  release:
    15→    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    16→    steps:
    17→      - name: Checkout
    18→        uses: actions/checkout@v4
    19→        with:
    20→          fetch-depth: 0
    21→
    22→      - name: Determine version bump
    23→        id: bump
    24→        if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    25→        env:
    26→          GH_TOKEN: ${{ github.token }}
    27→        run: |
    28→          BUMP="patch"
    29→
    30→          PR_NUMBER=$(gh pr list --search "${{ github.sha }}" --state merged --json number -q '.[0].number' 2>/dev/null || echo "")
    31→          if [ -n "$PR_NUMBER" ]; then
    32→            LABELS=$(gh pr view "$PR_NUMBER" --json labels -q '.labels[].name' 2>/dev/null || echo "")
    33→            if echo "$LABELS" | grep -q "release:major"; then
    34→              BUMP="major"
    35→            elif echo "$LABELS" | grep -q "release:minor"; then
    36→              BUMP="minor"
    37→            fi
    38→          fi
    39→
    40→          echo "type=$BUMP" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
    41→          echo "Version bump: $BUMP"
    42→
    43→      - name: Get next version
    44→        id: version
    45→        if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    46→        run: |
    47→          LATEST=$(git tag -l 'v*' --sort=-v:refname | head -n1)
    48→          BUMP="${{ steps.bump.outputs.type }}"
    49→
    50→          if [ -z "$LATEST" ]; then
    51→            case "$BUMP" in
    52→              major) NEXT="v1.0.0" ;;
    53→              minor) NEXT="v0.1.0" ;;
    54→              *)     NEXT="v0.0.1" ;;
    55→            esac
    56→          else
    57→            MAJOR=$(echo "$LATEST" | sed 's/v//' | cut -d. -f1)
    58→            MINOR=$(echo "$LATEST" | sed 's/v//' | cut -d. -f2)
    59→            PATCH=$(echo "$LATEST" | sed 's/v//' | cut -d. -f3)
    60→            
    61→            case "$BUMP" in
    62→              major) NEXT="v$((MAJOR+1)).0.0" ;;
    63→              minor) NEXT="v${MAJOR}.$((MINOR+1)).0" ;;
    64→              *)     NEXT="v${MAJOR}.${MINOR}.$((PATCH+1))" ;;
    65→            esac
    66→          fi
    67→
    68→          echo "tag=$NEXT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
    69→          echo "Next version: $NEXT"
    70→
    71→      - name: Create tag
    72→        if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    73→        run: |
    74→          git config user.name "github-actions[bot]"
    75→          git config user.email "41898282+github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
    76→          git tag ${{ steps.version.outputs.tag }}
    77→          git push origin ${{ steps.version.outputs.tag }}
    78→
    79→      - name: Create GitHub Release
    80→        uses: softprops/action-gh-release@v2
    81→        with:
    82→          tag_name: ${{ github.ref_type == 'tag' && github.ref_name || steps.version.outputs.tag }}
    83→          generate_release_notes: true
    84→

Perfect. Now I have all the information needed. Let me provide a comprehensive analysis:

## Summary Report: Marketing Site Content & Deployment Architecture

### 1. Blog Content System

**Location**: `/Users/jw/Desktop/repos/laxdb/packages/marketing/src/lib/posts.ts`

The marketing site uses **Content Collections (v0.13.0)** for blog management:

- **Configuration**: `packages/marketing/content-collections.ts` defines the MDX collection
- **Schema**: Posts require:
  - `title` (string)
  - `published` (ISO date)
  - `draft` (boolean, default: false)
  - `description`, `authors`, `tags` (optional)
- **Content Location**: `src/content/` directory (MDX files)
- **Build Step**: `bun run gen:content-collections` compiles MDX at build time
- **Runtime Access**: `publishedPosts` array exported from `posts.ts` filters out drafts

**How it works**:
- Posts are compiled to a `content-collections` module during build
- `publishedPosts` is a static array populated at build time
- Routes load posts from this array using `publishedPosts.find()` - zero runtime I/O
- MDX is pre-compiled to `post.mdx` (React component code)

**Routes**:
- `/blog/` - filtered listing (guides, opinion, wiki)
- `/content/{slug}` - individual post (MDX renderer)
- `/tag/{tagId}` - filter by tag
- `/wiki/` - knowledge base subset

### 2. GitHub Integration

**Current Usage**: Only via Alchemy IaC (CI/CD pipeline)
- `alchemy.run.ts` imports `GitHubComment` from `alchemy/github`
- Used to post PR preview deployment links
- **NO Octokit, NO direct GitHub API calls in application code**
- **NO releases fetching anywhere in the monorepo**

**GitHub Details**:
- Repo: `jackwatters45/laxdb` (hardcoded in footer and about page)
- Release workflow exists (`release.yml`) that auto-tags versions via semantic versioning
- Version detection uses git tags (`v*` pattern)
- GitHub Actions has `GITHUB_TOKEN` available at deploy time

### 3. Deployment Model: **SSR (Server-Side Rendering)**

**Critical for your use case**:

- **Build tool**: Vite with `@tanstack/react-start` plugin (TanStack Start framework)
- **Deployment**: Cloudflare Workers via Alchemy IaC
- **Architecture**: `alchemy()` plugin in `vite.config.ts` + `TanStackStart("marketing", ...)` in `alchemy.run.ts`
- **Output**: Not static files - generates server code at `.output/server/`
- **Runtime**: Runs on Cloudflare Workers (can fetch at request time)

**Key implication**: Unlike static SSG sites (Next.js export), TanStack Start deployed to Workers can execute server code at **request time**. This means:

✅ **POSSIBLE**: Fetch GitHub Releases at request time (during SSR)
✅ **POSSIBLE**: Cache responses in KV namespace
✅ **NOT NEEDED**: Pre-fetch at build time (though possible via build hooks)

**Server capabilities available**:
- `changelogEntries` is currently a **static array** in `src/lib/changelog.ts`
- Can be converted to a server loader function
- Alchemy provides `kv` namespace for caching (see `alchemy.run.ts` line 138)
- Workers can make outbound HTTP requests

### 4. Existing Changelog System

**Location**: `/Users/jw/Desktop/repos/laxdb/packages/marketing/src/lib/changelog.ts`

- **Current model**: Hardcoded TypeScript array of changelog entries
- **Route**: `/changelog` at `src/routes/changelog.tsx`
- **Component**: `ChangelogEntryCard` renders entries in timeline format
- **Schema**:
  ```typescript
  id, title, date, category, summary, body[], highlights[]
  ```
- **Categories**: data | feature | improvement | community
- **Sorting**: Done at runtime in the route component

**NO CHANGELOG.md** exists in repo root.

### Architecture Summary

```
GitHub Releases API
        ↓
    [Fetch at request time]
        ↓
TanStack Start Route Loader (server-side)
        ↓
    [Optional KV cache]
        ↓
Changelog component (client-side render)
        ↓
Cloudflare Workers (deployment)
```

### Key Technical Insights

| Aspect | Current | Relevant to Changelog Fetching |
|--------|---------|--------------------------------|
| Blog posts | Static array at build time | Shows Content Collections pattern works well |
| Deployment | SSR on Cloudflare Workers | Can fetch at request time |
| Data freshness | Build time only | Changelog could be fresher if fetched at runtime |
| Server-side code | Minimal (just routing) | Can add server loaders to routes |
| Caching | KV namespace exists | Could cache releases to avoid API rate limits |
| Type safety | Effect-TS in core, React in marketing | Can type GitHub API responses |

### Build/Deploy Pipeline

- `bun run dev` - Starts Vite dev server
- `bun run build` - Vite build → outputs to `.output/`
- `bun alchemy deploy` - Deploys to Cloudflare Workers
- Release workflow auto-creates GitHub tags based on PR labels (major/minor/patch)
